1.0    Emergency Response Plan

1.1    Sites Covered by Emergency Response Plan (Covered Sites)

    1.1.1    Trauger Pumping Plant
    1.1.2    El Mirador Booster Station
    1.1.3    Saddle Reservoir
    1.1.4    Tonyville Water Treatment Plant

1.2    Public Receptors

Public Receptors are sites likely to be more sensitive to chlorine releases. Public Receptors are defined in Environmental Protection Agency 40 CFR Part 68, Accidental Release Prevention and Risk Management Planning. Public Receptors are located within a calculated ?Estimated Distance to Toxic Endpoint?, determined by a model to be the furthest point that an acute, emergency release of chlorine would affect.

Public Receptors and the Estimated Distance to Toxic Endpoint are listed in Table 1.

1.3    Early Warning / Early Notification

In the event of a chlorine release from one of the Covered Sites, the following steps will be taken:

Assess the Incident ? If District personnel can safely bring the situation under control, then they will do so.

Evacuate the Premises ? If the release cannot be safely brought under control, evacuate the employees to higher ground upwind from the Covered Site. All personnel should meet at the designated evacuation assembly point listed on Table 1.

Look Around - Before leaving the facility, verify that all others have left the premises.

Call for Help ? Dial 911 and give information including facility location and telephone number, the quantity of chlorine involved, and the possible hazards to human health.

Help Injured Persons ? Help all injured persons as much as possible.

Report to Emergency Response Agencies ? Upon arrival of emergency personnel, the Emergency Coordinator shall report and provide assistance as requested.

Notification ? If the Emergency Coordinator determines that the situation is a threat to human health or the environment, the Tulare County Environmental Health office and the City of Visalia Fire Department is notified.
Emergency Response Plan

Reentry ? Reentry to the

facility is prohibited until the Tulare County Environmental Health office or the City of Visalia Fire Department or the Emergency Coordinator has given approval.

Submittal ? Any necessary or required spill release and notification forms will be submitted to the proper agencies.

1.4    Incident Command System and Training

    1.4.1    Agency Liaison

The organizational structure of the Lindsay-Strathmore Irrigation District Incident Command System is illustrated in Figure 1-1. Upon a threatened or real emergency chlorine release, the District Manager is designated as the Emergency Coordinator. In 

Emergency Response Plan
Page 3

the event the Manager is not available, the Assistant Manager is designated as the Emergency Coordinator. If the emergency release occurs during swing or graveyard 
shifts, the Operator on duty will act as the Emergency Coordinator until either the Manager or Assistant Manager arrives on site. The Emergency Coordinator is responsible for the evacuation of any employees on site to the proper evacuation sites listed in Table 1.

The Tulare County Environmental Health office is the agency with jurisdiction during an emergency chlorine release. The City of Visalia Fire Department, through and under contract with the Tulare County Environmental Health office, is the agency responsible for containment of an emergency chlorine release.

    1.4.2    Training

The Lindsay-Strathmore Irrigation District training program does not involve coordination with outside agencies. The Distri

ct completed initial 40-hour HAZWOPER training on April 22, 1999. Seldner Environmental Services of Valencia, CA conducted the course. The course syllabus included:

?    Regulatory Overview
?    Hazard Communication
?    Introduction to Toxicology
?    Hazardous Risk Management
?    Personal Protective Equipment
?    Monitoring and Sampling
?    Spill Control Techniques
?    Decontamination
?    Emergency Response Planning
?    Emergency Response
?    Safety and Health Programs
?    Standard Operation Procedures
?    Bloodborne Pathogens
?    Medical Surveillance
?    Lockout/Tagout
?    Confined Space Entry
?    Radiation Safety Management
